items.title: Magic Earth → Google Maps Converter – Turn One Link into Another in Seconds
items.summary: (Photo by Enrique Alarcon on Unsplash) The Magic Earth to Google Maps converter is…
items.content_html:
(Photo by Enrique Alarcon on Unsplash)

The Magic Earth to Google Maps converter is a free, web‑based utility that instantly rewrites a Magic Earth URL into a standard Google Maps link. It removes the friction of sharing location data across two competing navigation ecosystems, letting anyone—whether they’re on Android, iOS, or the desktop—open the same spot with the map service they already trust.

Why use the Converter?

Even if you love Magic Earth for its clean UI, offline maps, and privacy‑first design, you’ll still run into situations where the most people you share locations with—friends, family, coworkers—already rely on Google Maps. In those moments, the converter can help you keep navigating with Magic Earth on your end, but you hand over a Google Maps link that anyone can open instantly. It’s the best of both worlds—your preferred navigation experience stays untouched, while the people you’re sharing with get a hassle‑free, universally readable link. 

What the converter eliminates
  1. Universal compatibility – Any Magic Earth URL (or raw latitude/longitude pair) is turned into a standard Google Maps link that works on every device, browser, and operating system.
  2. Zero effort – A single click parses the original link and generates the new one; there’s no need to manually create coordinates.
  3. Seamless collaboration – Whether you’re planning a road‑trip pit‑stop, sending a meeting point, or helping someone locate a site, the recipient can open the location instantly in Google Maps.

How It Works – Under the Hood

  1. Input – You paste a Magic Earth link or the entire text provided by the magic earth app or the coordinates (raw latitude/longitude pair).
  2. Parsing – The script reads the query string, isolates the latitude and longitude parameters, and validates them.
  3. Formatting – It constructs a Google Maps URL of the form https://www.google.com/maps/search/?api=1&query=-62.17388669,-58.86386407
  4. Output – The new link appears instantly, ready to be copied or shared via a “Copy link” button.

Because the conversion is purely client‑side JavaScript, no server logs or personal data are stored—privacy‑conscious users can feel safe.

Step‑by‑Step Guide for End Users

  1. Open the converter page - Magic Earth to Google Maps Convertor

  2. Paste the input as below -
    • Entire text provided by Magic Earth:
      Check out this place, via Magic Earth app: Address: San Francisco, California, United States Latitude: 37.77925875 Longitude: -122.41932875
      https://magicearth.com/?show_on_map&lat=37.77925875&lon=-122.41932875&name
      =San+Francisco&city=San+Francisco&ctry=United+States&img_id=268435456
    • Magic Earth link:
      https://magicearth.com/?show_on_map&lat=37.77925875&lon=-122.41932875&name=San+Francisco&city
      =San+Francisco&ctry=United+States&img_id=268435456
    •  Coordinates:
      • "-62.17388669, -58.86386407"
      • "-62.17388669 -58.86386407"
      • "Latitude: -62.17388669, Longitude: -58.86386407"
      • "Latitude: -62.17388669 Longitude: -58.86386407"
      • "latitude: -62.17388669, longitude: -58.8638640"
  3. Click “Convert to Google Maps link”.
  4. Copy the generated Google Maps link (or hit the "Copy link" button to automatically add it to clipboard).
  5. Share the link.

Key Features Worth Highlighting

  • Free & Open Access – No registration, no ads, no hidden fees.
  • Instant Conversion – Sub‑second processing thanks to client‑side execution.
  • Cross‑Device Compatibility – Works on desktop browsers, mobile Safari/Chrome, and even within progressive‑web‑app shells.
  • Privacy‑First Design – All calculations happen locally; nothing is sent to a backend.
  • Extensible API – Developers can embed the conversion logic in their own apps via a tiny JavaScript snippet (link to GitHub repo if you have one).

Potential Enhancement

Adding a reverse‑conversion feature that instantly transforms a Google Maps URL into a Magic Earth link—or extracts the raw latitude/longitude coordinates—for seamless two‑way sharing.

Ready to try it yourself? Visit https://hswar.github.io/Magic-Earth-to-Google-Maps-Converter/, paste a Magic Earth link, and watch the magic happen.

items.title: YouTube Ad-Free: My Go-To Hacks
items.summary: (Image credit: HSWAR) For many of us, YouTube is a go-to platform…
items.content_html:
(Image credit: HSWAR)

For many of us, YouTube is a go-to platform for entertainment, learning, and much more. However, by default, YouTube does not offer an ad-free experience—unless you subscribe to YouTube Premium. Unfortunately, not everyone can afford this premium subscription. Additionally, some users who prioritize privacy may be hesitant to purchase YouTube Premium due to concerns about data collection and tracking.

In this article, I’ll share some methods I use to enjoy YouTube content.

1. My Experiemce with Brave Browser + YouTube
2. Using Ad Blockers
3. Third-Party YouTube Clients

My Experience with Brave Browser + YouTube

How I use brave on iOS

I mainly use the Brave browser on my iPhone to stream music from the YouTube website. Brave’s built‑in ad blocker gives me an entirely ad‑free experience, and its background‑playback feature keeps the audio running even when I switch to another app or lock my phone.

On iOS, Brave lets me create playlists from any website. I use this capability to add YouTube songs to a personal playlist. Those playlists sync effortlessly with CarPlay, allowing me to pick any track or video from the list and enjoy it through car’s speakers.

Brave on other platforms

Although I mainly use Brave on iOS, I’ve tested Brave on a handful of other devices to see how the YouTube experience compares.

On Android phones the ad‑blocking works just like on iOS, removing pre‑rolls and banner ads, and background playback lets the audio continue when I switch apps or lock the screen. The downside is that the Android version of Brave doesn’t let me create playlists directly in the browser, and it isn’t available in Android Auto.

On desktop computers—whether running macOS, Windows, or Linux—the Brave browser provides an ad‑free YouTube experience.

Using Ad Blocker Desktop Browsers

I mainly use an ad‑blocking extension on my desktop browsers. While there are many options on the market, my go‑to choice is uBlock Origin. It’s compatible with virtually every major browser and gives me a truly ad‑free experience. I install the uBlock Origin extension on both Chromium‑based browsers and Firefox‑based browsers, ensuring consistent protection no matter which platform I’m using. 

A lightweight version called uBlock Origin Lite is also available for Safari, although I haven’t tested it personally yet.

Chromium‑Based Browsers
  1. Open the Chrome Web Store: https://chromewebstore.google.com/
  2. Search for “uBlock”.
  3. Click Add to Chrome (or the equivalent button for your Chromium browser) and confirm the installation.
Firefox‑Based Browsers
  1. Visit the Mozilla Add‑ons site: https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/extensions/
  2. Search for “uBlock Origin”.
  3. Click Add to Firefox and follow the prompts to enable the extension.

Third-Party YouTube Clients

I mainly rely on two third‑party YouTube clients: NewPipe on Android and FreeTube on my laptop. Both apps are popular alternatives to the official YouTube client and offer features such as ad‑free playback, background audio, and the ability to download videos for offline viewing.

If you’d like to learn more about the full range of YouTube clients, feel free to check out my article on Must-Try YouTube Clients for Desktop and Android Devices.

For any unavailable icons, you can create or find similar ones using Icon Pack Studio. These setups are intended to inspire and provide ideas for customizing your own home screen. items.title: Must-Try YouTube Clients for Desktop and Android Devices
items.summary: (Image credit: HSWAR) As concerns about privacy and data tracking continue to…
items.content_html:
(Image credit: HSWAR)

As concerns about privacy and data tracking continue to grow, many users are exploring alternatives to the official YouTube app. These clients give you access to your favorite videos while bypassing some of the tracking and ad-related issues associated with the mainstream service. In this article, we recommend popular YouTube front-ends which deliver a variety of features tailored to different platforms and user needs.

1. NewPipe

Platforms: Android Linux

NewPipe is a lightweight, open-source YouTube client for Android that doesn’t require a YouTube account. It provides core functionality through parsing YouTube pages directly and does not rely on the YouTube API or Google Play Services. This means you can use it on devices where Google Services aren’t installed.

Key Features:

  • Video Search and Playback: Quickly search for and display general information about videos. Watch videos in resolutions up to 4K
  • Background Audio Playback: Listen to the audio stream in the background to save data.
  • Popup Mode (Floating Player): Enjoy a picture-in-picture experience.
  • Live Streams and Subtitles: Watch live streams and toggle subtitles/closed captions on and off.
  • Playlist Management: Enqueue videos, create local playlists, and get notifications about new uploads from your subscribed channels.
  • Download Capabilities: Download videos, audios, and subtitles (closed captions).
  • Content Providers: Besides YouTube, NewPipe also supports other services like PeerTube, SoundCloud, Bandcamp, and media.ccc.de.
  • Privacy and Open Source: It is FLOSS, meaning it’s completely open source and community-driven.

NewPipe also offers a legacy version for older Android devices (Android 4.1+) available on its website.

2. FreeTube

Platforms: Windows Mac Linux

FreeTube is an open-source desktop client for YouTube built with privacy as its priority. Aimed at providing a Google-free and ad-free YouTube experience on desktop platforms (Windows, Mac, and Linux), FreeTube leverages Electron for a consistent experience across different operating systems.

Key Features:

  • Ad-Free Viewing: Watch YouTube videos without the distraction of advertisements.
  • Enhanced Privacy: By preventing Google from using cookies or JavaScript to track your activity, FreeTube helps keep your data private.
  • API Access Through Tor: Make YouTube API calls over the Tor network for an added layer of anonymity.
  • Local Storage: Your subscriptions, watch history, and saved videos are stored solely on your computer and never sent to external servers.
  • User Experience Choices: FreeTube supports a mini player, as well as light and dark theme modes.
  • Beta Stage: While still in beta, FreeTube is steadily improving over time with new features and refinements.

Using FreeTube alongside privacy tools such as VPNs or Tor is advisable to enhance your identity protection.

Additional YouTube Clients to Consider

While NewPipe, and FreeTube are excellent options, there are a few other clients worth mentioning, such as Piped and Invidious. However, it's important to note that these services may experience occasional downtime or reliability issues.

Piped

Platforms: Online

Piped is an online frontend for YouTube that allows users to view content without connecting requests to Google. It offers a clean interface and various features to enhance the viewing experience, but users should be aware that it may not always be accessible.

Invidious

Platforms: Online

Invidious is another alternative that provides a privacy-focused way to watch YouTube videos without ads or tracking. Like Piped, it can sometimes face availability challenges, so users may need to try different instances or alternatives if they encounter issues.

 

Whether you prioritize privacy, ad-free viewing, or a lightweight interface, NewPipe, FreeTube, Piped, or Invidious offer excellent alternatives to the standard YouTube experience. Each client has its unique strengths, making them worth exploring for anyone looking to enhance their video consumption habits.

However, it's important to note that using these apps does not contribute to the views or watch time of the videos you watch. To support content creators and help them grow their channels, you will need to use the official YouTube app or website, or consider engaging with their content through other platforms they may provide.

Additionally, many content creators offer merchandise related to their channels, such as apparel, accessories, or digital products. Purchasing this merchandise is another great way to support your favorite creators while enjoying unique items that reflect their brand.
